name: Lipstick Plant
description: Aeschynanthus radicans, commonly known as the Lipstick Plant, is an epiphytic plant native to the humid tropics of the Malay Peninsula south to Java. It belongs to the Gesneriaceae family and features trailing stems (60-150 cm long) with leathery, dark green, ovate to lanceolate leaves (4-8 cm long). The plant displays a trailing or climbing growth habit, making it ideal for hanging baskets. It produces bright red, tubular flowers (5-7.5 cm long) that emerge from dark maroon calyces, resembling a tube of lipstick, hence its common name. The flowers bloom intermittently from spring to fall. In its native habitat, it grows as an epiphyte on tree branches in tropical forests. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds vibrant colors with its bright red flowers and glossy green foliage. It's popular among gesneriad enthusiasts for its showy flowers and trailing habit.
careTips: Keep substrate consistently moist but not waterlogged
Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feel dry
Can be grown in hanging baskets or mounted on bark
Prune after flowering to maintain bushy appearance
